head.title: The Cardinal's Gift: Looking Beyond Conflicts

hedline.hl1: The Cardinal's Gift: Looking Beyond Conflicts

abstract.p: John Devine letter on William F Buckley Jr's May 7 tribute to late Cardinal John O'Connor holds New York Archbishop might translate American thoughts to Rome instead of relaying decisions of Roman magisterium to American Catholics

block.p: William F. Buckley Jr. (Op-Ed, May 7) admiringly portrays the ''top down'' way in which Cardinal John O'Connor performed his role -- bravely and consistently relaying the decisions of the Roman magisterium to American Catholics -- as the only appropriate diplomatic style. But another, more dialogic model of teaching is also theologically acceptable: one in which the teaching authority always remains a learner, and every learner assumes the role of teacher.

William F. Buckley Jr. (Op-Ed, May 7) admiringly portrays the ''top down'' way in which Cardinal John O'Connor performed his role -- bravely and consistently relaying the decisions of the Roman magisterium to American Catholics -- as the only appropriate diplomatic style. But another, more dialogic model of teaching is also theologically acceptable: one in which the teaching authority always remains a learner, and every learner assumes the role of teacher.

If the hierarchical church still believes in the ancient adage ''vox populi, vox Dei'' (''the voice of the people is the voice of God''), then a different theology might emerge, one in which the archbishop of New York might indeed translate ''American thoughts'' to Rome and in which Rome would listen with respect.
The writer is a former Jesuit priest.
